channel.title: "Harvard, MIT to partner in $60 million initiative to offer free online cla.."

item.title: "Harvard, MIT to partner in $60 million initiative to offer free online cla.."
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Apparently the courses are watered down versions of what they actually teach. If you visit the coursera website, you can enroll in them. They typically offer two types of enrolment: assignment based, where you’re issued with assignments to complete and due dates etc, and non-assignment based, where you just watch the videos and complete the weekly tests.

At the end, you get a certificate with a disclaimer that basically says it isn’t worth anything at all.
With that said, if you’re already in the industry then go wild – may as well take what you can get if it’s free. But it’s not a pathway into a career for those who don’t already have some kind of industry recognition in the form of a degree/diploma/etc.

Read full topic
item.source: "Harvard, MIT to partner in $60 million initiative to offer free online cla.."

item.title: "Harvard, MIT to partner in $60 million initiative to offer free online cla.."
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Rather exciting, though I wonder how much interaction you get with the course creators. I have used the iOS development course from Stanford via iTunes U and that was rather good, they provide you with the course material, assignments, etc, but you obviously do not have that interaction from the lecturers.

Also if anyone has not tried out any of the iTunes U stuff, there is some pretty good stuff on there, they have wrapped it up in a nice UI (http://i.imgur.com/j7X2v.jpg) for the iPad and iPhone but you can download all the standard files from iTunes.

From how they describe this it seems to be a lot more involving than just getting access to course content, so that is good, with ‘guidance’ of professors and assistants. Regardless, it should still be good.

Read full topic
